title: Bounding the Mim-Width of Hereditary Graph Classes

sections.two summary theorems:
In our first summary theorem we give all pairs (H1,H2)subscriptğ»1subscriptğ»2(H_{1},H_{2}) for which the mim-width of the class of (H1,H2)subscriptğ»1subscriptğ»2(H_{1},H_{2})-free graphs is bounded.
This theorem gives more bounded cases than the corresponding summary theorem for boundedness of clique-width of classes of (H1,H2)subscriptğ»1subscriptğ»2(H_{1},H_{2})-free graphs, which can be found inÂ  and which we need for our proof. Cases (i)â€“(ix) follows from the fact that each of the classes of (H1,H2)subscriptğ»1subscriptğ»2(H_{1},H_{2})-free graphs in these cases has bounded clique-width and that clique-width is quickly computable for general graphsÂ .
For CaseÂ (i) we also refer to TheoremÂ 3.19.
Boundedness of clique-width has been proven for Case (ii) as follows: inÂ  for K1,3+3â€‹P1subscriptğ¾133subscriptğ‘ƒ1K_{1,3}+

It has been proven for CaseÂ (viii) andÂ (ix) inÂ   andÂ , respectively. CasesÂ (iii),Â (v),Â (vii) follow from CasesÂ (ii),Â (iv) andÂ (vi), respectively, after recalling that the clique-width of a class of (H1,H2)subscriptğ»1subscriptğ»2(H_{1},H_{2})-free graphs is bounded if and only if the clique-width of the class of (H1Â¯,H2Â¯)Â¯subscriptğ»1Â¯subscriptğ»2\left(\overline{H_{1}},\overline{H_{2}}ight)-free graphs is boundedÂ [ref]38.
CasesÂ (x) andÂ (xi) follow from TheoremsÂ 4.13 andÂ 4.9 respectively.
Case (xii) has been proven inÂ .
Cases (xiii)â€“(xv) follow from TheoremsÂ 4.1â€“4.5, respectively. For our second summary theorem, we turn to the unbounded cases.

either a cycle of length at leastÂ 444 or

CasesÂ (i) and (iii) follow from TheoremÂ 3.12 and LemmaÂ 3.15, respectively, possibly after applying LemmaÂ 3.2 a sufficient number of times. All three subcases of CaseÂ (ii) follows from TheoremÂ 5.8. The first subcase of CaseÂ (iv) follows from TheoremÂ 5.1, the second one follows from TheoremÂ 5.15, the third one follows from TheoremÂ 5.11 and the fourth one follows from TheoremÂ 5.15. All three subcases of CaseÂ (v) follow from LemmaÂ 3.18. CaseÂ (vi) follows from TheoremsÂ 5.9 andÂ 5.3. All subcases of CaseÂ (vii) follow from LemmaÂ 3.16.
CaseÂ (viii) follows from TheoremÂ 5.15. We note that the situation for the unbounded cases is again different from the situation for the unbounded cases of clique-width. For example, (H1,H2)subscriptğ»1subscriptğ»2(H_{1},H_{2})-free graphs have unbounded clique-width if both H1Â¯âˆ‰ğ’®Â¯subscriptğ»1ğ’®\overline{H_{1}}

otin{\cal S}, so (H1,H2)subscriptğ»1subscriptğ»2(H_{1},H_{2})-free graphs have unbounded clique-width. However, by TheoremÂ 6.1-(xiii), (H1,H2)subscriptğ»1subscriptğ»2(H_{1},H_{2})-free graphs have bounded mim-width.
As (H1Â¯,H2Â¯)Â¯subscriptğ»1Â¯subscriptğ»2(\overline{H_{1}},\overline{H_{2}})-free graphs have unbounded mim-width by TheoremÂ 6.3-(i),
this example also shows that the complementation operation, a standard tool for working with clique-width, does not preserve mim-width. Consequently,
for mim-width there are many more open cases than the only five open cases for clique-widthÂ .
